texts.en: Charity is a 28 year-old married woman. She has 2 children between 2 years and 8 years. She describes herself as aggressive, determined, and focused. She operates a salon business where she provides hair and beauty services to the local people. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her business is located in a shopping center and her primary customers are ladies since she specializes in doing ladies' hair. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate salon equipment. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to add stock of cosmetics to meet customer demands, especially as we approach the festive season. Her business goal is to grow her business into a beauty college within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will provide quality education to her children.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is single but he helps his parents to pay school fees for his siblings.  He is in the motorcycle transportation business.  He has been in the business for the past year and he earns a monthly income of KES 6,000 from the business.

This is his first loan term in KADET.  He will use the loan to open a retail shop, which will be managed by his mother.  He will use the anticipated profits to buy another motorbike.  His dream is to be financially stable and educate his siblings.

loans.use: Diversify the business

loans.name: Maximo

texts.en:
Maximo is married, with 4 children. Maximo is 60 years old and lives in Valconcha St Aguada, Ozamiz City.
To earn a living, Maximo has a boarding house business.  He has had this business for 8 years. Each month, he earns approximately PHP 20,000.  He has requested a loan of 50,000 PHP to purchase equipment for his boarding house business.   Maximo has been a member of PMPC for 4 years.
In the future, Maximo hopes to improve his living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase equipment for his boarding house business

loans.name: Suwono

texts.en:
Suwono is a 36-year-old man who is married to Asiyah, a 36-year-old lady. They are blessed with three children namely: Muhammad, 6, attending first grade of Elementary School; Firas, 4, and Nirmala, 1. 

Suwono sells cakes such donuts, fried tofu, fried bananas, bread, etc. and instant cold beverages such as milk, juice, orange juice and “es cendol” (a kind of traditional beverage made of ice, melted palm sugar, doughy rice flour droplets and coconut milk).

He has been involved in this business since 1995. He operates the business in front of his house from 6 am to 10 pm. Most of his customers are senior high school and vocational school students as his residence is located near the schools. 

Suwono would like to add more cakes such as muffins and soybean cakes and also other beverages. Therefore, Suwono is seeking a loan of IDR 3,000,000 from TLM to implement his plan. He is expecting that TLM will be willing to provide him with the loan to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase cake ingredients and instant cold beverage mixes.

loans.name: Anichka

texts.en: Anichka is from the village of Amasia in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is married and has a thirty-six-year-old son.  Anichka has a high school education and has been a farmer for the past 21 years.  With produce grown on the family farm, Anichka supports her relatives living in the city of Gyumri.  She considers herself a hard worker and would like a loan to purchase livestock and feed.  Anichka expects her income to increase by twenty percent with this investment.  She is pleased with the terms and conditions of microfinance.  Anichka dreams of saving enough money to provide for her grandchildren’s education.  She enjoys the life of a farmer living in Amasia.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and feed

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is 58 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with seven children. 

Lucia has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for ten years. She requested a loan for 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy canned goods, snacks, and rice.

Lucia has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Lucia hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and rice.

loans.name: Tunuk's Group

texts.en:
Tunuk is the leader of this group. She is 51 and, unfortunately, she is a widow. All her sons are adults; they live and work in Bishkek. At the moment Tunuk lives with her grandchildren. From time to time the sons transfer money to their mom for buying agricultural seeds and farm animals for breeding. Tunuk breeds poultry. This year, with the profit gained from selling the harvest, she purchased chickens and enlarged a shed. With the money she receives from the loan, she wants to purchase more chickens for breeding. In the near future, she plans to increase the number of cattle because in her opinion it is an effective way of investing money.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a lideo presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase chickens for breeding.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a lot of empty plastic cans

loans.name: Zipporah Mueni

texts.en:
Zipporah is a 26-year-old married woman. She describes herself as business-minded. She operates a a general store with a grocery corner where she sells flour, sugar, rice, cooking oil, detergents, fruits, vegetables and more. She has been involved in this business for three years. 

Her business is located in a shopping center. She says her biggest business challenge is inflation. She will use the Kes 80,000 loan to stock general items.

Her business goal is to grow her business into a big supermarket within five years. She hopes that, in the future, she will own a piece of land and a car.

loans.use: to stock four, sugar, cereals, fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Tabutha

texts.en:
Tabutha is 32 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is married and has three children with two of them currently in school. For the past seven years, Tabutha has been working hard to manage her grocery store, which sells food and home supplies to local customers. 

To help expand her business, Tabutha has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food items for sale and will help Tabutha generate greater profits and provide for her family. Tabutha hopes that in the future she will be able to have a big business and educate her children. 

Tabutha is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Tabutha who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more food items to sell

loans.name: Maria Salome

texts.en: Maria Salome is a widow with three children. She is 37 years old and lives in Ozamis City, Philippines. Maria Salome owns and operates a motorcycle transport business to earn a living, and she's been in this business for two years. Each month, she earns 5,600 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 20,000 to purchase motorcycle spare parts for better service. Maria Salome has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. In the future, Maria Salome wants to have another motorcycle for transport.

loans.use: to purchase motorcycle spareparts

loans.name: Bukeru

texts.en:
Bukeru is 43 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri, which is located in the Iganga region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past 24 years, Bukeru has been working hard to manage and operate his grocery store, which sells food and home supplies to local customers.

To help expand his business, Bukeru is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food items like passion fruit, Irish potatoes, etc., and will help Bukeru to generate greater profits and to thereby improve his family's standard of living. Bukeru hopes that in the future he will be able to open grocery stores in more locations.

Bukeru is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Bukeru who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: To buy additional food items (e.g., passion fruit and Irish potatoes)

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda is 47 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children. 

Brenda has a retail shop that sells food supplements, cosmetics, detergents, and clothes from GOOD FAITH products. She has had this business for three years. She requested a loan for 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy stocks from GOOD FAITH to sell.

Brenda is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Brenda hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy stocks from GOOD FAITH to sell

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is a 44-year-old, married mother of one child. She operates a grocery store in Malindi town. She has been in this business for the past ten years, and she earns a monthly income of approximately 20,000 KES.

Martha has applied for a loan in the amount of 30,000 KES from KADET LTD, which would serve as her first loan cycle. She intends to use part of her loan proceeds to add additional groceries for resale purposes, including fruits and vegetables, and to use the rest of the loan proceeds to pay school fees for her child.

Martha hopes to use the anticipated profits from her business as a result of the requested loan to continue supporting her child while also saving for future investments.

loans.use: To buy additional inventory (e.g., assorted fruits and vegetables).

loans.name: Anahit

texts.en: Anahit is from the village of Anoushavan in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is the proud mother of a 27-year-old daughter and a 31-year-old son.  She was educated as a nurse and has been working with her husband on the family farm for twenty years.  Anahit helps to support her relatives with fruits and vegetables grown on the family farm.  She is known for being a hardworking, honest person.  Anahit would like a loan to increase her livestock.  According to her plan, this investment will increase her income by 15%.  In addition to helping her children, Anahit dreams of renovating the family home.  Even though life is difficult, she enjoys being a farmer living in Anoushavan.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more food items, such as sugar, maize and rice

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is 35 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children. 

Marites has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

Marites is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Marites hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is married to Mary, and together they have two children who both attend school. He is a carpenter and has been in the business for the past seven years. He earns a monthly income of KES 30,000 from his business.

This is his first loan from KADET LTD. He will use the loan to increase his stock of wood to make more furniture and purchase a wood cutting machine.

He will use the anticipated profits to expand the business by opening another outlet. His dream is to have three outlets in Nairobi.

loans.use: to purchase stock and another machine

loans.name: Afliana

texts.en:
Afliana is a 56-year-old entrepreneur married to Daniel, a 63-year-old farmer. They have four children: Aryance, 35; Yuliana, 33; Moses, 31 (who are married) and Thomas, 25, (who is studying accounting at a local university).

Afliana has been engaged in a poultry business since 2004. The business enables her to assist her husband in generating more income for the family and supporting Thomas' education. 

She commenced the business by purchasing the chicks from the supplier. She raises them by feeding and providing them with water and vitamins for a three-week period. Afliana usually sells the chicks to her customers. 

Afliana intends to expand the business by adding more chicks to raise so she will be able to generate more income. Afliana said that she needs a lot of money to finance Thomas' education at the university. To solve that problem, Afliana and husband decided to seek a loan of IDR 5,000,000 from TLM. She plans to purchase more chicks, fodder, and vitamins and to build a water tank for the chicks. She is hoping that TLM will approve her loan application.

loans.use: to purchase more chicks, fodder, and vitamins and to build a water tank for the chicks

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is married to Philomena, and together they have one child. He distributes bread, and he raises livestock and poultry. He has been in the farming business for the past two years. He earns a monthly income of KES 6,000 from the business.


This is his first loan term from KADET LTD. He will use the loan to purchase animal feed and more poultry.


With the expected profit, he will rear pigs at his farm. His dream is to have a stable income to support his young family.

loans.use: to purchase animal feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy chemicals used for making disinfectants and detergents

loans.name: Rofilo

texts.en:
Rofilo is 39 years old and lives in the Philippines.  He is married with four children.

Rofilo has a retail shop that sells a variety of dried fish.  He has had this business for five years.  He requested a loan for 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy stocks of dried fish to sell.

Rofilo is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Rofilo hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy stocks of dried fish to sell

loans.name: Venera's Group

texts.en:
Venera is the leader of this group. She is 39 and she is divorced. She brings up two sons and a daughter. The daughter studies at university and the sons go to school. Venera works in a microfinance company; in 2003 she purchased a house with a garden.  Since that time she has been cultivating agricultural products. Selling some part of the harvest she earns additional 3000 soms to meet the family needs. With the profits gained from the trade she started building a shop. Venera applies for the loan because she needs additional funds to purchase building materials to finish a construction of the shop. In the future she plans to finish the construction and lease it out to diversify her sources of income and for making additional money to family budget.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase building materials for her shop

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a 32-year-old business woman who lives in Juba. She is married and has seven children between the ages of 2 and 16. Six of them go to school. 

Rose runs a food store business and has been in the business for five years. She has no employees. Rose heard about Finance Sudan through other clients. She is taking a loan of 1000 SDG to purchase more food items like onions, groundnut paste, tomatoes, and many others. Other than this business, Rose has no other source of income.

In five years' time, Rose would like to hope for the increase of her business size.  

Her major challenges include low income and home expenses.   

Rose says that she is happy for Finance Sudan’s support in South Sudan, which has enabled clients to pay for their children's schooling.

loans.use: to purchase more food items like onions, groundnut paste, and tomatoes

loans.name: Hasmik

texts.en: Hasmik is from the town of Artik in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She was born in Artik and has lived her whole life there.  Hasmik has a high school education and also has been trained as an accountant.  Due to the limited number of jobs in Artik, Hasmik began farming five years ago.  This has brought income for the family and allowed her to help her relatives living nearby.  Hasmik would like a loan to purchase livestock and feed.  She expects the family income to increase by twenty percent with the investment.  Hasmik has four wonderful children – three daughters (twenty, twenty-five and twenty-eight years old) and a nineteen-year-old son.  She wants her business income to grow so that she can continue supporting her children and grandchildren.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and feed

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher is 31 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with three children. 

Christopher has a shop that sells green and yellow bananas and coconuts. He has had this business for five years. He requested a loan for 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy coconuts and bananas to sell.

Christopher is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Christopher hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy coconuts and bananas to sell

loans.name: Geronedes

texts.en:
Geronedes is 56 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children. 

Geronedes has a shop that sells bananas and coconuts. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy coconuts and bananas to sell.

Geronedes has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Geronedes hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy coconuts and bananas to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to grow his working capital so he can buy a lot of foodstuffs.

loans.name: Yendri

texts.en:
Yendri is a 69-year-old farmer married to Sarah, a 63-year-old lady. They have been blessed with eight children. They are: Simon, 45; Deky, 41; Yakomina, 40, and Adri, 36 who are married and work as farmers. There is also Matje, 38 and Mery, 34, who are both married; Ridwan, 32, and Ricky, 30. Yendri and his wife are living with six of their children. Simon and Deky live separately. 

At his current age, Yendri still has the spirit to work hard for his family. Yendri has a plot of land that he inherited from his parents. He cultivates rice, cabbage, chili and tomatoes. He usually works at the farm from early morning to evening. Sometimes his wife helps him. 

Yendri is planning to rent a plot of land from his neighbor for six years to cultivate more vegetables such as “kangkung,” water spinach, chili, tomatoes and corn but he needs money to do so. He is seeking for a loan of IDR 7,500,000. He would like to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide. He hopes that TLM will approve the application.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 31 years old and married to Thomas. They have four children who are aged ten, five, three and one year old.  Jane is a tailor and has been for the past year. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD to enable her to buy another sewing machine and material for clothes.

She hopes to expand her business and open a tailoring shop in the future.

loans.use: To buy another sewing machine and materials to add to her stock.

loans.name: Celsa

texts.en: Celsa is separated from her husband, and she has two children. Celsa is 35 years old and resides at Aguada, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental: Philippines. Celsa owns and operates a general store to earn a living.  She's been 5 years in this business.  Each month, she earns 20,000PHP.  She requested a loan of 30,000 PHP to purchase more goods to sell.  Celsa has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. In the future, Celsa wants to have a rice mill.

loans.use: to purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase float for her M-pesa (Mobile money transfer services)

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 41 years old and is married to Michael. They live in Kakamega and have one grand child.  Grace has a charcoal business, which she has been doing for the past six years. 

She has applied for a loan to enable her to buy materials for making the charcoal burners.  She hopes to be the leader charcoal dealer in her town.

loans.use: To buy materials for making charcoal burners

loans.name: Hanan

texts.en:
Hanan is a 41-year-old married woman from Marka, Amman Jordan and the mother of four children.

Hanan is requesting a loan of 400 JD to purchase home furniture.

An aspiration of Hanan's is to purchase her own car.

Due to cultural issues, the man in the picture is Hanan's husband.

loans.use: to purchase home furniture

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel is married, with 4 children. Maribel is 30 years old and lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental.  Maribel has a general store and has had this business for 2 years. Each month, she earns PHP 3,000 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 30,000PHP  to purchase stock for her general store.
Maribel has been a member of PMPC for 2 years.  In the future, Maribel hope to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase stock for her general store

loans.name: Elida

texts.en: Elida is from the village of Erazgavors in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is happily married with three sons (fourteen, nineteen and twenty-two years old).  Elida has a high school education and has been working as a farmer for the past twenty years.  Her eldest son will soon marry and she would like to help him with the wedding costs.  She also dreams of renovating the family house.  Elida would like a loan to purchase additional cattle.  She expects this investment to bring the family thirty percent additional income.  She has a positive opinion of microfinance and the opportunity to expand her business.  She enjoys living in her native village of Erazgavors near her relatives and good friends.

loans.use: purchase additional cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more livestock to add to his stock.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 53 year-old married woman. She has 8 children with ages ranging from 5 years to 28 years. She describes herself as being determined and social. She operates a farm where she produces vegetables. She has been involved in this business for 10 years and employs 1 staff member. Her primary customers are institutions. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the high cost of farming activities and fluctuating prices for inputs. 

She will use the Kes 80,000 loan to pay school fees for her dear children. Her business goal is to grow her business by developing a fish pond within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will own a fish pond and an orchard.

loans.use: To pay her children's school fees

loans.name: Esther Nduku

texts.en: Esther is a 41 year-old married woman. She has 4 children with ages ranging from 8 months to 18 years. She describes herself to be humble. She operates a grocery store where she sells vegetables to the local people. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her business is located in a shopping centre and her primary customers are households. She describes her biggest business challenge to be fluctuating prices. She will use the Kes 80,000 loan to purchase a motorcycle that will facilitate the running of the business. Her business goal is to grow her business into wholesale within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will open other stalls that will specialize in the sale of groceries.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle that will facilitate the running of the business

loans.name: Ata Allah

texts.en:
Ata Allah is a 53-year-old married man from Marka, Amman, Jordan and a father of five children.

Ata Allah has his own bakery and he is requesting a loan of 1500 JD to do maintenance for his bakery and purchase raw materials.

Ata Allah is looking to open another branch of his bakery and finance the education of his children in school.

loans.use: to do maintenance and purchase materials.

loans.name: Bonifacia

texts.en:
This is Bonifacia, 67, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is a widow, and mother of five children.  All of them are already working and have their own families.  At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Bonifacia operates a dried fish stall. What she basically does is buy dried fish from a wholesaler and then repack them and sell them per piece/pack at a profit. Products can range from dried fish to dried anchovies and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low prices and the many options she offers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Bonifacia dreams of expanding her store and helping her children through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stock of dried fish needed in her business

loans.name: Adelaide

texts.en: Adelaide is a 27-year-old married woman. She describes herself to be visionary. She operates a retail shop where she sells food items, detergents, paraffin, and other general items. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in a shopping center, and her primary customers are household shoppers. She describes her biggest business challenges to be inflation and the low purchasing power of her customers. She will use the 30,000-Kenyan-shilling (KES) loan to stock food items, detergents, and paraffin. Her business goal is to grow into wholesale within five years. She hopes that in the future she will purchase a van that will facilitate the running of her business.

loans.use: to increase stock of food items, detergents, paraffin, and other goods

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to grow her working capital so she can buy large quantities of tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Beatrice Musabi

texts.en:
Beatrice, a 43-year-old married woman, has four children ranging in age from 5 to 18 years. Describing herself as visionary, for the past three years she has been operating a retail shop located in a shopping centre selling food items, detergents, utensils and other general items. She describes her biggest business challenges as inflation and a poor transportation network.

Beatrice will use the Kes 20,000 loan to purchase more food items, detergents and utensils. Her goal is to grow her business into a wholesale enterprise within five years, and she hopes to eventually purchase a plot of land upon which to build rental units.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of general items.

loans.name: Aidyn's Group

texts.en:
Aidyn is the leader of this group. She is 35 and her husband works in Russia; therefore, she takes care of their children by herself.  She has two sons and a daughter; all the children study at school. AIdyn works as a laboratory assistant. Ten years ago with an initial investment of 5,000 soms she started to breed livestock. At the moment she keeps fifteen goats and she wants to increase the number of livestock. For this purpose she applied for the loan. With money received from the loan Aidyn wants to purchase three sheep. In the future she plans to save money to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep.

loans.name: Nelly Ambogo

texts.en: Nelly is a 41-year-old married woman. She has 5 children with ages ranging from 5 years to 15 years. She describes herself to be visionary. She operates a cereals sales business where she sells cereals and also ice cream. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a shopping center. She describes her biggest business challenges to be inflation and a poor road transport network. She will use the Kes 30,000 loan to add a stock of maize. Her business goal is to grow her business into wholesale within 5 years. She hopes that in the future she will open another cereals shop.

loans.use: To add a stock of maize.

loans.name: Samia

texts.en:
Samia is a 50-year-old married woman from Madaba, Jordan and a mother of eight children. She is requesting a loan of 500 JD to purchase an incubator for her chickens. 

Samia is looking to improve her business and expand her project space.

loans.use: to purchase an incubator.

loans.name: Entesar

texts.en:
Entesar is a 35-year-old married woman from Madaba, Jordan and a mother of four children. She is requesting a loan of 800 JD to do maintenance for her home.

An aspiration of Entesar's is to improve her house and renew her home appliances.

loans.use: to do maintenance for her home.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase clothes for resale.

loans.name: Mary Adhiambo

texts.en: Mary is a married woman. She has 2 children aged 2 and 5 years. She describes herself to be soft spoken, humble, and loving. She operates a retail shop where she sells items which include sugar, flour, detergents etc. She has been involved in this business for 4 years and employs 1 staff member. Her business is located in a shopping centre. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the poor sewerage system that affects the customer inflow to her business area. She will use the KES 15,000 loan to add to her stock of items like sugar and detergent. Her business goal is to grow into wholesale within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will provide better living standards for her family.

loans.use: To increase her stock of items like sugar, detergents, and others

loans.name: Sirvard

texts.en: Sirvard lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Karnout.  Karnout is far from the noise of the city and the air is fresh.  There are few economic opportunities except for farming and raising livestock.  Sirvard has been engaged as a farmer for the past nineteen years.  Owing to the services of microfinance she has been able to grow her business.  The terms and conditions are fair and rates are going down.  Sirvard would like a loan to purchase additional cattle and seeds.  This loan will help her increase the family income by twenty percent.  She would like to save some money to renovate her house and start a dairy production business.  She is pleased with her life and her wonderful husband, son, and daughter.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and seeds

loans.name: Mai

texts.en:
Mai is a 48-year-old married woman from Madaba, Jordan and a mother of two children.

Mai has a childcare business and she is requesting a loan of 500 JD to purchase new toys and beds for the children.

Mai is looking to expand her childcare business by moving it away from her home.

loans.use: to purchase  new toys and beds for her childcare business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is a 32 year-old married woman. She has a child who is 3 years old. She describes herself to be loving. She operates a clothing business where she sells clothes to the local people. She has been involved in this business for 4 years and employs 1 staff member. Her business is located in a shopping centre. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient capital. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to add to her stock of clothes. Her business goal is to grow her business and open other stalls in Nairobi within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will provide employment to many jobless Kenyans when her business grows.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more stock of clothes and kitchenware for sale

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
This is Virginia, 58, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is a widow and a mother to her two children. She, together with her children, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Virginia maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 5,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 43,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Virginia hopes to be more successful with her business and dreams to be able to give her children a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for merchandise items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Aigul's Group

texts.en:
Aigul is a member of this group. She is 31 and resides in Kadamjai, a small town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She works with a public fund, and her parents are engaged in cattle breeding. At the moment Aigul needs additional funds to pay the tuition at her university, and is applying for a loan for this purpose. In the future she hopes to graduate from university, and dreams of then becoming a lawyer.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society); Planet (remaining environmentally friendly); and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.  If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team: Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to pay the tuition at her university.

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
This is Marissa, 61, a resident of Manila, Philippines. Her husband is Rolando, and she is the mother to her three children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Marissa maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealers' prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 4,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 26,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Marissa hopes to be more successful with her business and dreams to be able to give her children a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for merchandise items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to increase his capital to buy large quantities of fabric to make clothing in order to realize large profits

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
This is Leticia, 53, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Ramon, a vendor, and a mother to their three children.  She, together with her husband and children, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Leticia operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Leticia hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Gayane

texts.en: Gayane is from the village of Hovouny in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is married with three daughters (twenty-two, twenty-eight and thirty years old).  Gayane has a high school education and has been working as a farmer for the past fifteen years.  As times are difficult in Armenia, Gayane supports her daughter’s families with produce grown on the family farm.  She considers herself a hardworking person and is looking for a loan to purchase animal feed and seeds.  The autumn planting season is near and Gayane wants to grow her business.  The loan will help her increase the family income by ten percent.  Gayane was born in Hovouny and enjoys living there.  She dreams of renovating the family home.

loans.use: to purchase animal feed and seeds

loans.name: Irine

texts.en:
Irine lives in the Coastal town of Mombasa, Kenya.  She is married and has two children; the elder one goes to school.  She has been operating an open-air clothes and shoe business for six years. The business attracts a number of customers who pass along the path on daily basis.

Irine has been a client of Milango for close to one year and is applying for a KES 80,000 loan to enable her buy additional stock of clothes, shoes and umbrellas in readiness for the Christmas festivities.  The loan will also improve the family’s income and their standard of living. The main challenge for this business is the rainy season; her business is not sheltered. Her main aim is to finish building her house and move into it, then build a business premises.

loans.use: To buy additional stock of clothes, shoes and umbrellas

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Marmashen.  She is married and has a two-year-old son.  Anna finished college with a teaching degree.  With difficult economic times, she has been farming the family land for the past five years.  She is working hard and would like to expand her business.  She would like a loan to purchase additional livestock.  She expects this investment to grow her net income by fifteen percent.  She is pleased with the services of microfinance and the reasonable rates.  Anna dreams of renovating her home.  She was born in Marmashen and enjoys the rural life.

loans.use: to purchase additional livestock

loans.name: Yassah

texts.en:
Yassah is 51 years old and live in Barnersville. She is married and has six children between the ages of 8 and 32.  Three are working and living on their own, while the others are presently in school and live at home.  Her husband is a businessman. 

For the past twenty years Yassah has been selling alcoholic drinks in her community, and is now requesting a loan to purchase more alcoholic drinks like “white spirit”, “big mama”, “apple fresh”, and “black hours” for her business.  She likes the ways people respond to her business.  Her plan is to build a house for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more alcoholic drinks like “white spirit”, “big mama”, “apple fresh”, and “black hours” for her business.

loans.name: Mama

texts.en:
Mama is 44 years old and lives in Barnersville. She is married and has five children between the ages of 8 and 25. One is presently in school, others are working and living on their own, and the youngest one is living at home.  Her husband is a social worker. 

For the past four years Mama has been selling oil, rice, pepper and eggs, and is now requesting a loan to purchase more inventory for her business.  She like the ways people respond to her business.  Her plan is to become a big businesswoman.

loans.use: to purchase more oil, rice, pepper, and eggs for her business.

loans.name: Carolyn

texts.en: Carolyn is a 36 year old married lady who is blessed with two children aged 9 and one year old. Only one child who is 9 years old goes to school. She has been running a tailoring and dressmaking business in Nairobi to make a living since 2002. She has employed one person to help her run the business. The major challenge she has faced is competition. She is requesting a loan for 70,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy fabric. In the next five years, she wants to become more financially stable. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, she has been able to manage her business with her previous loan. She describes herself as hardworking, visionary and committed.

loans.use: to buy stocks of fabric

loans.name: Nderagakura Group

texts.fr:
Mathias est un commerçant âgé de 39ans qui habite la localité de Kwibuka de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Il fait le commerce d’articles divers (haricots, souliers, riz, savons, huile, souliers…) dans son kiosque depuis 10 ans. Il a commence cette activité lorsqu’il travaillait pour un autre commerçant. Il a fait ses études jusqu’en 6e année primaire. Il est marie a Beatrice, une cultivatrice et ont ensemble 5 enfants dont 4 étudient a l’école primaire. 
 Le crédit Kiva  de 250,000 francs burundais qu’il obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter de grandes quantités d’articles divers (haricots, souliers, riz, savons, huile, souliers…)  pour son kiosque à revendre  afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices. 

Il est membre  du groupe  communautaire« NDERAGAKURA»
texts.en:
Mathias is a businessman aged 39 who lives in Kwibuka in the province of Gitega in the center of the country. He has been selling various items (beans, shoes, rice soap, oil, etc.) in his stall for 10 years. He began this activity when he was working for another businessman. He attended school up to 6th grade. He is married to Beatrice, a farmer, and together they have five children of whom four are enrolled in primary school. 

The Kiva loan of 250,000 Burundi francs that he will receive will allow him to grow his working capital so as to buy big quantities of various items (beans, shoes, rice, soap, oil, etc.) for his stall so as to make a lot of profit. 

He is a member of the group called "NDERAGAKURA".

loans.use: to grow his working capital so that he can buy large quantities of various items (beans, shoes, rice, soap, oil) to sell in his stall.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy electrical gadgets and clothes for sale

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 59 years old and married to Margaret. Together they have five children aged 16, 14, 13 and two 11 year olds. He is a carpenter and has been in the business for the past 30 years. He gets a monthly income of about KES 33,000 from the business.

This is his second loan through KADET. He paid his previous loan successfully. He will use the loan amount to purchase lumber, varnish and other carpentry materials.

He will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for his children and reinvest in the business. His dream is to stabilize his business and have enough cash flow to meet his family's needs.

loans.use: to purchase lumber and varnish.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en: Isaac is a 33 year old hard working business man. He is married and blessed with three children. He has been operating Baba Juniour business as a  bread distributor for the last six years. He has employed two people to help him to manage the business. In the next five years, he wants to expand his business. He wants to diversify into puncture repair business and thus he is requesting for a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy a puncture machine. Since Isaac joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to access loan funds to boost his business.

loans.use: To buy a puncture machine

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a forty-six-year-old married woman with seven children, four of whom attend school while the others are all grown up. Her husband Mwinyihaji is a businessman who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. She has a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children. 

Mwanajuma has operated a vegetable grocery for the past four years. Her potential clients are her neighbors, friends and relatives. She faces a major challenge of transporting her products to the market. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase vegetables and fruits for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to do business.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and fruits for resale.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 62 years old. He is married to Beth and they have six grown up children.

Francis operates a luggage transport business in Migori town and has been doing this for the last thirteen years. His business involves carrying luggage using a handcart, and in some cases he uses a donkey tied to this cart. This kind of business is doing well in this area because of the poor road network; thus, people prefer such means since it is possible to reach remote areas. He is taking his second loan which he will use to buy a new luggage cart and a donkey for this transport business.

Francis will plow his profits back into the business as well as pay his loan without default. His hope is to build a good house for his family.

loans.use: To buy a new cart and donkey for his transportation business.

loans.name: Safenaz

texts.en:
Safenaz is a 37 years old young woman. She is married and has one daughter. Her husband is a Palestinian National Authority employee with a decent salary. 

Safenaz wants to purchase new home furniture such as bedroom furniture, living room seats, etc. The amount of money she has isn't enough to pay for the furniture, so she needs to take a loan in the amount of $2,000 from FATEN. When Safenaz gets the loan, she will be able to purchase new home furniture and provide better living conditions for her family. 

Safenaz is a conservative woman, so her husband is photographed instead in a FATEN branch.

loans.use: to purchase new home furniture.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon is married to Esther. He is a carpenter and has been in the business for the past two years. His monthly income from the business is about KES 10,000. This is his first loan term from KADET LTD. He will use the loan amount to purchase wood to make furniture. The anticipated profits will be used to open another outlet. His dream is to have a stable income to care for his family.

loans.use: to purchase wood.

loans.name: Bakari

texts.en:
Bakari is a thirty-four-year-old married man with seven school-going children. He has a house with neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food for his family and school fees for his children. 

Bakari has operated a retail shop for the past six years. His potential clients are his relatives and friends. He faces a major challenge of seasonality. He dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 80,000 he wants to purchase ten bundles of maize flour and four gallons of cooking oil for his shop. He decided to join Yehu because of the easy accessibility of loan facilities.

loans.use: To purchase ten bundles of maize flour and four gallons of cooking oil for his shop.

loans.name: Abdu

texts.en:
Abdu is a thirty-four-year-old married man with four children, three of whom attend school while one is too young for school. His wife Mwanaidi is a businesswoman who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. He lives in a rental house with electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expense is school fees for his children. 

Abdu has operated a retail shop for the past eleven years. His potential clients are his neighbors and friends. He faces a major challenge of transporting his goods to his shop. He dreams of establishing a wholesale shop.

With the Kshs 60,000 he wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil for his shop. He decided to join Yehu to access funds to do business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil for his shop.

loans.name: Jemal

texts.en:
Jemal is from the village of Teleti. He is 67 years old and lives with his wife, Tsisana. Jemal and Tsisana are both retired and get a monthly pension (in total $120 USD per month). They have children who already have their own families and live separately. Jemal and Tsisana assist financially their children. 

They earn a living through agriculture. They have three milk cows and produce various dairy products, which are sold locally. The average monthly income of the family, including pensions, is 500 laris (approximately $300 USD).

Jemal requested credit for purchasing an additional milk cow. They will be able to produce and sell more dairy products and increase the income received from the dairy farm by 30 – 35 percent. Jemal plans to use the earned profit in finalizing the construction process of their own house.

loans.use: To purchase a milk cow.

loans.name: Mwanamkasi

texts.en:
Mwanamkasi is a forty-eight-year-old married woman with five school-going children. Her husband Rashid is a businessman who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. She has a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Mwanamkasi has operated a food stall for the past ten years. Her potential clients are her neighbors, friends and relatives. She faces a major challenge of seasonality where there are low sales during the rainy seasons. She dreams of opening a retail shop away from her home since she is currently selling from a section of her house.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase three crates of tomatoes and also buy some charcoal and firewood for her new business. She decided to join Yehu because of the easy accessibility of loan facilities to low income earners.

loans.use: To purchase three crates of tomatoes and also buy some charcoal and firewood for her new business.

loans.name: Najmeh

texts.en:
Najmeh is 40 years old.  She is a mother of eight sons and daughters. One of her children is married.

She has been working as a hair stylist for the last 18 years in her own beauty salon. Her salon started small and through the years, she was able to add more seats and new sections to the salon.

Now Najmeh has applied for this loan in order to buy more beauty products such as make-up to use in the salon and to sell. She also wants to buy more equipment that is needed in the salon, like hair dryers and other items.

loans.use: to buy more beauty products and equipment for her salon including hair dryers and makeup

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a forty-five-year-old married woman with four school-going children. Her husband Omari is a businessman who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. She has a house with electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Halima has operated a coconut selling business for the past six years. Her potential clients are the people who come to the market. She faces a major challenge of lack of market for her products. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase ten sacks of coconuts for resale. She decided to join Yehu because of its easy accessibility of loan facilities.

loans.use: To purchase ten sacks of coconut for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more oil, rice, pepper, and beans for her business.

loans.name: Manana

texts.en:
Manana lives in the village of Misaktsieli, Kartli Region. She is 50 years old. She is married and lives with her family: husband Ioseb and three daughters (26, 25 and 20 years old). The younger daughter is a student. 

The family earns a living through agriculture. They have three milk cows and a calf. Manana produces cheese and yogurt and sells it in the village on weekends. Along with the dairy farm, the family owns a greenhouse, with the area of 300 sq meters. In fall and winter months the greenhouse is used for greens growing and in spring and summer, tomatoes are grown there. The family sells harvested products locally to the greengrocery retailers. Total average monthly income of the family is 1100 Laris (approximately $660 USD). 

Manana requested credit for renovation of the greenhouse. It needs urgent renovation, as is already old and can’t keep the needed temperature. When Manana and Ioseb fix it, they will count on a good harvest of greens this fall and winter and sell it for a good price.

loans.use: to purchase materials for greenhouse renovation.

loans.name: Suad

texts.en:
Suad is a 42-year-old mother of two sons and two daughters.

Four years ago, Suad bought a sewing machine and started a small business at home sewing clothes and curtains to add another income source to the family. Now Suad has applied for a loan in order to buy another sewing machine to be able to raise her productivity level and make more profit.

loans.use: to buy another sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase chicken feed, 50 chicks and a dairy cow for her new business.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a 40-year-old married woman who opened a small retail place five years ago to sell clothes, cosmetics, and perfumes.

Today, Fatima is applying for a loan to improve the store decoration so it appears more attractive to the customers and to add more types of cosmetics to the store.

loans.use: to improve the store decoration, and buy more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Tushirikiyane Group

texts.fr:
Safia est une commerçante âgée de 31ans qui habite au centre ville de  Gitega au centre du pays. Elle fait le commerce de produits alimentaires (riz et haricots) depuis 5 ans. Elle a commence cette activité lorsqu’elle était cultivatrice. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 6e année primaire. Elle est mariée a Dieudonné et ont ensemble 2 enfants dont 1 étudie. 
 Le crédit Kiva  de 320,000 francs burundais qu’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter de grandes quantités de produits alimentaires (riz et haricots) à revendre  afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  communautaire« Tushirikiyane»
texts.en:
Safia is a businesswoman aged 31 who lives in the center of town in Gitega in the middle of the country. She has been selling foodstuffs (rice and beans) for five years. She began this business when she was a farmer. She attended school up to 6th grade. She is married to  Dieudonné and together they have 2 children of whom one is enrolled in school. 

The Kiva loan of 320,000 Burundi francs that she will receive will allow her to grow her working capital to buy large quantities of foodstuffs (rice and beans) for resale so that she can make a lot of profit. 

Safia is a member of the community group called "Tushirikiyane".

loans.use: to grow her working capital to buy big quantities of foodstuffs (rice and beans) for resale.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is from the village of Manglisi, Kartli Region. She is 47 years old and lives with her family: husband, Shota, her 17-year-old daughter and 86-year-old mother-in-law. Maria’s daughter goes to school. Her mother-in-law is retired. Maria and Shota earn a living with agricultural activities. They have two milk cows and sell milk in the village. 

Maria requested credit for purchasing an additional milk cow. She will get 50% more milk and increase the income of the family. 

The family members plan to use the increase in income for purchasing household goods in order to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow.

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Justina is 50 years old and live in Barnersville. She is married and has eight children between the ages of 20 and 27 years old, seven of whom are out of high school, working and living on their own, while the younger one is currently in school and lives at home. Justina's  husband is a businessman.
For the past thirty years, she has been operating a cook shop (restaurant). She is requesting a loan to purchase more oil, rice, pepper, onion, and coal for her business. She has more customers and makes higher profits. Her plan is to build a house for her children and send them to college.

loans.use: to purchase more oil, rice, pepper, onion and coal for her business

loans.name: Mariétou Tabaski

texts.fr: Madame Mariétou habite au Sénégal. Elle a choisi comme activité le commerce et gère une boutique ou elle commercialise des vaisselles dans la localité ou elle vit. Elle a choisi son activité par amour. Elle est membre de l’un des guichets de l’U-IMCEC depuis plusieurs années. Elle y a déjà contracté 2 prêts antérieurs. Elle sollicite un crédit de 150 000 frs prévu pour l’achat de vaisselles  qui seront destinées a renforcer son  stock dans la boutique. L’augmentation de ses bénéfices lui permettra de mieux se prendre en charge et aussi de soutenir les membres de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mariétou lives in Senegal. She has chosen to work as a retailer and she manages a shop selling crockery in her neighborhood. She chose this work as she enjoys it very much. 

She has been a  member of one of the branches of U-IMCEC for several years. Through U-IMCEC she has already received 2 previous loans. She is asking for a loan of 150,000 francs to buy crockery in order to increase the stock in her shop. Earning more profit will allow her to better meet her expenses and also to support the members of her family.

loans.use: to buy crockery for re-sale.

loans.name: Hamadallah

texts.en:
Hamadallah is a 19-year-old young man who is able to have a small store in A. Mafraq to sell cell phones and accessories. 

He has been working for three years and, at the same time,  he has been going to one of the Jordanian universities to study chemistry. With the store profits, he pays his school fees.

To make more profit in the store, he learned how to fix mobile phones and added it as a new service, which brought in more customers to the shop.

Now Hamadallah has applied for this loan in order to buy used cell phones to fix and re-sell in addition to the new ones that he already has in his store.

loans.use: to buy used cell phones to repair and sell

loans.name: Sonnie

texts.en: Sonnie is 32 years old and lives in Barnersville. She is married to a police officer. They have two children, 1 and11 years old. One is currently in  school, while the younger is look after by his mother. Both children live at home. Sonnie is a high school graduates. For the past five years she has been selling charcoal in her community. She is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal  for her business. She like the ways people respond to her business. Her plan is to build a house for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal  for her business

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Aziza is a 38-year-old widow.  She was left with a four-year-old daughter to raise.

To be able to do that, Aziza started to sell cleaning materials and detergents in the neighborhood two years ago. Her business has been going well regarding supporting her kid.

Now Aziza is hoping to widen her business to be able to provide the bigger stores with detergents to make more profit, so she has applied for this loan to get the quantity of detergents she needs at a wholesale price.

loans.use: to buy more detergent at a wholesale price

loans.name: Dilia Rosney

texts.es:
Dilia es una madre cabeza de hogar, tiene 2 hijos que ha sacado adelante mediante su propio negocio,  vende mecato, gaseosa, licor y cigarrillos, en una pequeña caseta ubicada en el sector comercial del barrio la Tabla, en el occidente antioqueño.

Hace 3 años atrás compro su caseta, pero por problemas de violencia en el sector, en los últimos meses se han reducido sus ventas y ha ocasionado que su surtido baje, por eso actualmente solicita un crédito para comprar más variedad de productos con el fin de mejorar sus ventas y por consiguiente sus ingresos, con el deseo de ahorrar para conseguir un local mejor ubicado que le permita mayores ingresos y por consiguiente mejor calidad de vida para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Dilia is a mother head of household; she has two children that she’s supporting through her own business.  She sells snacks, soft-drinks, liquor and cigarettes in a small booth located in the commercial sector of La Tabla neighborhood in west Antioquia.

She purchased her booth three years ago but due to the problem of violence in the sector sales have dropped the last few months and her stock has been reduced.  Because of this she’s asking for a loan to buy a larger variety of products in order to improve sales and thus her income hoping to save up in order to get a better situated locale that will lead to higher income and better quality of life for her children

loans.use: to buy assorted and varied merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 48 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is married and has four children. One of them currently in school. For the past four years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her small store, which sells stationary. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stationary supplies, and will help Sarah to generate greater profits and install internet in her shop. Sarah hopes that in the future she will be able to learn how to drive. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sarah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more stationary supplies for sale

loans.name: Arafati

texts.en:
Arafati is 35 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. He is married and has two children who are both currently in school.  Arafati has been working hard to manage his bakery, which makes bread, doughnuts and cakes. 

To help expand his business, Arafati has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more wheat for breadmaking, and will help Arafati to generate greater profits and improve the quality of life for his family. Arafati hopes that in the future he will be able to set up another bakery. 

Arafati is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Arafati who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more wheat for breadmaking,

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema lives in  Uganda. She is married and has 7 children, all of whom are in school. Rehema has a business of a food stall. She has been in this business for over 10 years. She works 7 days out of every week. Rehema sells her products in a market, by means of retail. Rehema has requested a loan of from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bananas, tomatoes, onions, and sweet and Irish potatoes. She also generates additional income through rental rooms. The main business challenges for Rehema include seasonality and thieves. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked stall. Rehema lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bananas, sweet and irish potatoes, onions and tomatoes

loans.name: Tinh's Group

texts.en:
Tinh is 56 years old with 3 children. She is living in An ninh village. She is running a small shop that sell fruits. This kinds of business creates stabL. income for her to manage her family life. She wants to a loan of 5,152,000 VND to buy more fruits to sell.

Than is 54 years olds. She is a farmer who focuses on growing rice and raising pigs. She wants to have a loan of 5,152,000 to buy food for pigs.

loans.use: To buy more fruits for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy chicks to raise and then sell

loans.name: Doviko

texts.en: Doviko, 38, is a married father of five children and owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. Formerly a butcher, he has been in the transport business for 15 years. His business hardship is high fuel prices, and his goals are to have a bigger truck and to educate his children. Doviko is requesting this loan in order to service his car.

loans.use: to service his car.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy merchandise like scarves, wool caps and wool gloves.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis is a forty-five-year-old married man with seven children. He has been in a commercial farming and timber business for twenty years. He used to practice subsistence farming but now is into commercial farming. His hardships are price fluctuations, inflation, high fuel and transportation prices and inadequate capital. His personal goal is to educate his children; his business goal is to expand into new markets. Francis needs the loan to buy manures and mulches and to pay labor.

loans.use: to buy manures and mulches and to pay labor.

loans.name: Marto

texts.en: Marto is 23 years old and lives in Barnersville. She is single, and she is a high school graduate. For the past three years she has been operating a cook shop (restaurant) in her community. She is requesting a loan to purchase more oil, rice, pepper, salt and onions for her business. She likes the way people respond to her business. Her plans are to build a house and attend college in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more oil, rice, pepper, salt and onions for her business.

loans.name: Lemi

texts.en:
Lemi is 38 years old, married to Rachael. Together they have two children aged eight and two years old. He is a carpenter and has been in the business for the past seven years. He gets a monthly income of KES 18,000 from the business.

This is his third loan. He paid his previous loans successfully. He will use the loan amount to purchase timber, varnish, and old furniture for repair and resale.

He will use the anticipated profit to pay school fees for his children and also provide for the family's basic needs. His dream is to purchase the necessary business tools in order to handle bigger furniture vendors.

loans.use: to purchase timber, varnish, and old furniture

loans.name: Tinh

texts.en: Tinh is 34 years old and has 2 children. As a farmer, she is growing rice to support her family's food needs and also to sell a part to earn income. Besides, she raises 5 pigs for meat. Ms. Tinh joined our credit program in 2009. She has used loans to buy fertilizer and to expand her pig-raising. Currently, she wants to receive a loan of 8,736,000 VND to buy food for her pigs.

loans.use: to buy food for her pigs

loans.name: Efusa

texts.en:
Efusa is 49 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. He is married and has five children. For the past five years, Efusa has been working hard to manage his retail shop, and is now raising around 700 birds to sell. 

To help expand his business, Efusa has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sugar and foods for resale and will help Efusa to generate greater profits and improve the quality of life for his family. Efusa hopes that in the future he will be able to build another chicken farm. 

Efusa is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Efusa who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more sugar and foods for resale

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet lives in Uganda. She is married and has 7 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members. Juliet has a business of a selling local gin.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Juliet sells her products at the market. Juliet has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more jerycans of local gin.  She also generates additional income through a restaurant.The main business challenge(s) for Juliet include seasonlity, transportation, and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to be a wholesaler and also to educate her children up to university level. Juliet lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication, and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more jerrycans of local gin

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is 48 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is widowed and has three children. For the past three years, Harriet has been working hard to manage her small retail shop, which sells sugar, soap etc.

To help expand her business, Harriet has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sugar, soap and cooking oil for her shop, and will help Harriet to generate greater profits and improve the quality of life for his family. Harriet hopes that in the future she will be able to build another residential house. 

Harriet is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Harriet who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, soap and cooking oil  for her shop

loans.name: An

texts.en: An is 38 years old and has 3 children who are attending school. She is running a shop that sell clothes in a local market. She gets stable income from this shop. As a client of SEDA credit program in 2009, she used most loans to invest in her shop. For the new loans cylce, she requires a loan of 9,814,000 VND to buy more styles of clothing to meet the demand of customers for coming season.

loans.use: To buy more style of clothing for sale

loans.name: Turaje Group

texts.fr:
Concilie est une commerçante âgée de 42ans qui habite la localité de Kibimba de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle fait le commerce de la bière locale  depuis 28ans. Elle est aussi cultivatrice. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’au niveau de l’alphabétisation. Elle est mariée a Melchiade ; un maçon et ont ensemble 5 enfants qui étudient. 
 Le crédit Kiva  de 100,000 francs burundais qu’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter de grandes quantités de bière locale à revendre  afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  communautaire« Turaje»
texts.en:
Concilie, aged 42 years, is a merchant who lives in the town of Kibimba, in the province of Gitega, in the center of the country.  She has been in the business of selling local beer for 28 years.  She is also a farmer.  She has had enough schooling to be able to read.  She is married to Melchiade, a mason, and together they have 5 children who attend school.
The Kiva loan of 100,000 Burundi francs that she will get will increase her working capital and allow her to buy large quantities of local beer to sell in order to make good profits. 
She is a member of the community group “Turaje.”

loans.use: to buy large quantities of local beer to sell in order to make good profits.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica lives in Uganda. She is married and has 8 children, all of whom are in school. Monica has a business of a liquor store. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Monica sells her products in a shop, by means of retail. Monica has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more jerrycans of local Gin. She also generates additional income through a restaurant.The main business challenges for Monica include seasonality, transportation and thieves. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a build rental rooms and also to educate her children up to university. Monica lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of local Gin

loans.name: Lan

texts.en: Lan is 42 years old with 2 children. She has been rice noodle maker for 4 years. Joining in our credit program in 2009, she has received 2 previous loans which she has used effectively to expand her business. She finds that this kind of credit is very suitable with her earning activity. She wants to borrow 9,184,000 VND to buy rice as material for making noodles.

loans.use: to buy material to make rice noodles

loans.name: Neema-Kimara Group

texts.en:
Rehema, who is in her early 30s is married with two children who are still going to school. She has been running three different types of businesses. She has a grocery store, sells charcoal and has a motor cycle for five years now. She works from 6 a.m to 6 p.m daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be her 6th motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.
